It is with considerable disappointment that I write this update but I believe in being transparent with residents, whether the news is good or in this case, not so good.
As it stands LCC are not going to agree to providing the funding to fill the gap in the double yellow lines on Village Way. I have copied below some of the relevant sections of the most recent responses from officers to illustrate the decision-making process.
I am disappointed that I have not been able to get this scheme delivered for you (yet), however I will continue to seek solutions and I will work with the relevant portfolio holders and officers to identify funding opportunities as and when they become available.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì
Dear County Councillor Riggott
I refer to your email of 27 April.
Whilst both elected divisional county councillor and cabinet member for highways and transportation may respond to a petition; I can confirm that we have not received a response in respect to the petition regarding extending the double yellow lines on Village Way, Buckshaw Village.
Observations have been carried out on Village Way, Buckshaw Village on the following dates:
3 March 2017 AM drop off
17 March 2017 PM pick up
28 March 2017 PM pick up
20 April 2017 AM drop off
The presence of parked vehicles within urban areas is a common occurrence and can result in lower traffic speeds due to the requirement for vehicles to give way to opposing traffic flows. Village Way at this location features excellent visibility of oncoming traffic in both directions and we would expect approaching vehicles to comply with procedures laid down in the Highway Code to ensure that they do not come into conflict with other road users. Village Way currently is currently subject to an advisory 20mph speed limit during school start and finish times with a mandatory speed limit of 30mph outside of these times.
Observations carried out to date have revealed that vehicles are approaching the crossing location with appropriate caution and that the location is currently operating satisfactorily in terms of road safety which is supported by the historical lack of incidents in the vicinity.
Information provided by the Police confirms that the incident referred to occurred on Sunday 5 March 2017 with the Police in attendance at 14:31hrs. The driver of the vehicle was detained at the scene for a drink driving offence and there is no association between the circumstances of this incident and weekday school traffic or parking behaviour at the location.
I appreciate our decision is disappointing we have a responsibility to allocate our finite resources based up on greatest need.
As the highway authority we have a finite budget and a responsibility to prioritise our resources that best serve the residents and road users in Lancashire. Our current priority is to target those resources at locations with significant numbers of injury accidents, in addition to schemes that will contribute to the improvement of the highway network.
The road safety record at this location is good with no recorded injury accidents occurring in the past 5 years or longer. Notwithstanding your constituents concerns, when we have locations that do have a history of collisions causing injury and sadly fatalities that are competing for funding for traffic schemes, it would be remiss of the county council to divert the limited funding we have to locations that do not. Therefore we are unable to support further measures at this junction at the present time.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì
Dear County Councillor Riggott
I refer to your email of 18 May.
The councils commitment is to prioritise funding on fulfilling our statutory responsibility of maintaining a safe highway network. We have seen reductions in both available budget and staff and our limited resources, in particular to traffic related issues we are focussed in delivering schemes which has a demonstrable positive impact in reducing casualty figures; it would therefore be remiss of the council to consider delivering traffic schemes at locations where there is a good safety record when there are still so many locations with very poor accident statistics currently waiting and competing for funding for schemes. This is the mandate set by the council and as such it is not within officers discretion to consider delivering schemes which does not fulfil our prioritisation strategy.
Following on from this meetings with members is very resource intensive and a county council directive was issued nearly 2 years ago which acknowledged this in light of the much reduced staffing levels the county council now supports with an increased demand in services. Site visits are only considered if they will be mutually beneficial i.e. we have funding options or the officer needs a better understanding of the issue at hand. Neither criteria falls within your requests for visits as officers fully understand the issues at hand and notwithstanding your desire for a positive way forward we have no scheme options and our position would be unchanged despite meeting and therefore we are unable to justify that it is a good use of our finite resources.

As it stands LCC are not going to agree to providing the funding to fill the gap in the double yellow lines on Village Way. I have copied below some of the relevant sections of the most recent responses from officers to illustrate the decision-making process.
I am disappointed that I have not been able to get this scheme delivered for you (yet), however I will continue to seek solutions and I will work with the relevant portfolio holders and officers to identify funding opportunities as and when they become available.

Dear County Councillor Riggott
I refer to your email of 27 April.
Whilst both elected divisional county councillor and cabinet member for highways and transportation may respond to a petition; I can confirm that we have not received a response in respect to the petition regarding extending the double yellow lines on Village Way, Buckshaw Village.
Observations have been carried out on Village Way, Buckshaw Village on the following dates:
3 March 2017 AM drop off
17 March 2017 PM pick up
28 March 2017 PM pick up
20 April 2017 AM drop off
The presence of parked vehicles within urban areas is a common occurrence and can result in lower traffic speeds due to the requirement for vehicles to give way to opposing traffic flows. Village Way at this location features excellent visibility of oncoming traffic in both directions and we would expect approaching vehicles to comply with procedures laid down in the Highway Code to ensure that they do not come into conflict with other road users. Village Way currently is currently subject to an advisory 20mph speed limit during school start and finish times with a mandatory speed limit of 30mph outside of these times.
Observations carried out to date have revealed that vehicles are approaching the crossing location with appropriate caution and that the location is currently operating satisfactorily in terms of road safety which is supported by the historical lack of incidents in the vicinity.
Information provided by the Police confirms that the incident referred to occurred on Sunday 5 March 2017 with the Police in attendance at 14:31hrs. The driver of the vehicle was detained at the scene for a drink driving offence and there is no association between the circumstances of this incident and weekday school traffic or parking behaviour at the location.
I appreciate our decision is disappointing we have a responsibility to allocate our finite resources based up on greatest need.
As the highway authority we have a finite budget and a responsibility to prioritise our resources that best serve the residents and road users in Lancashire. Our current priority is to target those resources at locations with significant numbers of injury accidents, in addition to schemes that will contribute to the improvement of the highway network.
The road safety record at this location is good with no recorded injury accidents occurring in the past 5 years or longer. Notwithstanding your constituents concerns, when we have locations that do have a history of collisions causing injury and sadly fatalities that are competing for funding for traffic schemes, it would be remiss of the county council to divert the limited funding we have to locations that do not. Therefore we are unable to support further measures at this junction at the present time.

As it stands LCC are not going to agree to providing the funding to fill the gap in the double yellow lines on Village Way. I have copied below some of the relevant sections of the most recent responses from officers to illustrate the decision-making process.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì
Dear County Councillor Riggott
I refer to your email of 27 April.
Whilst both elected divisional county councillor and cabinet member for highways and transportation may respond to a petition; I can confirm that we have not received a response in respect to the petition regarding extending the double yellow lines on Village Way, Buckshaw Village.
Observations have been carried out on Village Way, Buckshaw Village on the following dates:
3 March 2017 AM drop off
17 March 2017 PM pick up
28 March 2017 PM pick up
20 April 2017 AM drop off
The presence of parked vehicles within urban areas is a common occurrence and can result in lower traffic speeds due to the requirement for vehicles to give way to opposing traffic flows. Village Way at this location features excellent visibility of oncoming traffic in both directions and we would expect approaching vehicles to comply with procedures laid down in the Highway Code to ensure that they do not come into conflict with other road users. Village Way currently is currently subject to an advisory 20mph speed limit during school start and finish times with a mandatory speed limit of 30mph outside of these times.
Observations carried out to date have revealed that vehicles are approaching the crossing location with appropriate caution and that the location is currently operating satisfactorily in terms of road safety which is supported by the historical lack of incidents in the vicinity.
Information provided by the Police confirms that the incident referred to occurred on Sunday 5 March 2017 with the Police in attendance at 14:31hrs. The driver of the vehicle was detained at the scene for a drink driving offence and there is no association between the circumstances of this incident and weekday school traffic or parking behaviour at the location.
I appreciate our decision is disappointing we have a responsibility to allocate our finite resources based up on greatest need.
As the highway authority we have a finite budget and a responsibility to prioritise our resources that best serve the residents and road users in Lancashire. Our current priority is to target those resources at locations with significant numbers of injury accidents, in addition to schemes that will contribute to the improvement of the highway network.
The road safety record at this location is good with no recorded injury accidents occurring in the past 5 years or longer. Notwithstanding your constituents concerns, when we have locations that do have a history of collisions causing injury and sadly fatalities that are competing for funding for traffic schemes, it would be remiss of the county council to divert the limited funding we have to locations that do not. Therefore we are unable to support further measures at this junction at the present time.

This is the mandate set by the council and as such it is not within officers discretion to consider delivering schemes which does not fulfil our prioritisation strategy.

This year was again an incredibly successful year for Buckshaw Youth Association.
We opened for a total of 30 Friday evening sessions with membership passing the 250 mark for the second successive year and total attendance passing the 2000 mark, again for the second successive year.
Our average weekly attendance was 68, reaching peaks of 90+ on multiple occasions.
As always, I am eternally grateful for the support provided by my fellow Trustees, Secretary Alan Platt and Vice Chairman Lee Williams. Without them, Buckshaw Youth Association would not exist.
I must thank all those who joined the team to volunteer their time including Simon from RMGBuckshaw, PCSO Ray Chadwick, local resident Vicky Thompson and Michelle Graham from Chorley Youth Zone. Again I must thank our home grown former members Heather Watson, Jack Grover, Alice Reeves, Harvey Taylor and Chelsea Edgington who help lead the sessions on a Friday evening.
Once again we were joined by the team from MACY (Music & Arts for Creative Youth) ably led by Zoe and Marie who ran their popular wide variety of craft and creative projects, with support from wider members of the MACY team to bringing in karaoke sessions and drama workshops.
At Christmas we joined forces with many organisations including The BVCA ( Buckshaw Village Community Association ), Buckshaw Village Church, Friends of Buckshaw Village, RMG, SJL Heating & Plumbing, Buckshaw Leaflet Distribution and many others to hold the first combined Christmas Event in Buckshaw Village. It was a fabulous and highly memorable occasion that will be tough to beat next time around and I would personally like to thank all those involved who made it happen. I would also like to thank local Councillors Debra Platt and Mark Jarnell for their grants towards the cost of the Christmas tree.
We once again have been issuing Lancashire Time Credits to volunteers and have issued in excess of 200 Time Credits this year. Our Facebook page (now with 185 Likes) is proving popular in keeping parents informed of our weekly activities and opening dates, as is our Twitter account.
Finally I must once again thank Alan Platt for the continued variety his purchasing brings to our tuck shop, Lee Williams for his never ending mopping and sweeping on a Friday night and for the good humour they both bring as well as the support and advice they offer to those members leading the Friday evening sessions. It is hugely appreciated.
Thanks Aidy

It is with considerable disappointment that I write this update but I believe in being transparent with residents, whether the news is good or in this case, not so good.
As it stands LCC are not going to agree to providing the funding to fill the gap in the double yellow lines on Village Way. I have copied below some of the relevant sections of the most recent responses from officers to illustrate the decision-making process.
I am disappointed that I have not been able to get this scheme delivered for you (yet), however I will continue to seek solutions and I will work with the relevant portfolio holders and officers to identify funding opportunities as and when they become available.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì
Dear County Councillor Riggott
I refer to your email of 27 April.
Whilst both elected divisional county councillor and cabinet member for highways and transportation may respond to a petition; I can confirm that we have not received a response in respect to the petition regarding extending the double yellow lines on Village Way, Buckshaw Village.
Observations have been carried out on Village Way, Buckshaw Village on the following dates:
3 March 2017 AM drop off
17 March 2017 PM pick up
28 March 2017 PM pick up
20 April 2017 AM drop off
The presence of parked vehicles within urban areas is a common occurrence and can result in lower traffic speeds due to the requirement for vehicles to give way to opposing traffic flows. Village Way at this location features excellent visibility of oncoming traffic in both directions and we would expect approaching vehicles to comply with procedures laid down in the Highway Code to ensure that they do not come into conflict with other road users. Village Way currently is currently subject to an advisory 20mph speed limit during school start and finish times with a mandatory speed limit of 30mph outside of these times.
Observations carried out to date have revealed that vehicles are approaching the crossing location with appropriate caution and that the location is currently operating satisfactorily in terms of road safety which is supported by the historical lack of incidents in the vicinity.
Information provided by the Police confirms that the incident referred to occurred on Sunday 5 March 2017 with the Police in attendance at 14:31hrs. The driver of the vehicle was detained at the scene for a drink driving offence and there is no association between the circumstances of this incident and weekday school traffic or parking behaviour at the location.
I appreciate our decision is disappointing we have a responsibility to allocate our finite resources based up on greatest need.
As the highway authority we have a finite budget and a responsibility to prioritise our resources that best serve the residents and road users in Lancashire. Our current priority is to target those resources at locations with significant numbers of injury accidents, in addition to schemes that will contribute to the improvement of the highway network.
The road safety record at this location is good with no recorded injury accidents occurring in the past 5 years or longer. Notwithstanding your constituents concerns, when we have locations that do have a history of collisions causing injury and sadly fatalities that are competing for funding for traffic schemes, it would be remiss of the county council to divert the limited funding we have to locations that do not. Therefore we are unable to support further measures at this junction at the present time.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äì
Dear County Councillor Riggott
I refer to your email of 18 May.
The councils commitment is to prioritise funding on fulfilling our statutory responsibility of maintaining a safe highway network. We have seen reductions in both available budget and staff and our limited resources, in particular to traffic related issues we are focussed in delivering schemes which has a demonstrable positive impact in reducing casualty figures; it would therefore be remiss of the council to consider delivering traffic schemes at locations where there is a good safety record when there are still so many locations with very poor accident statistics currently waiting and competing for funding for schemes. This is the mandate set by the council and as such it is not within officers discretion to consider delivering schemes which does not fulfil our prioritisation strategy.
Following on from this meetings with members is very resource intensive and a county council directive was issued nearly 2 years ago which acknowledged this in light of the much reduced staffing levels the county council now supports with an increased demand in services. Site visits are only considered if they will be mutually beneficial i.e. we have funding options or the officer needs a better understanding of the issue at hand. Neither criteria falls within your requests for visits as officers fully understand the issues at hand and notwithstanding your desire for a positive way forward we have no scheme options and our position would be unchanged despite meeting and therefore we are unable to justify that it is a good use of our finite resources.
